title: Coerced murder (kill-or-be-killed)
vignette: A tyrant tells Reuven: “Kill Shimon or I will kill you.”

options.text: Refuse; accept death rather than murder.
Comply; kill Shimon to preserve your own life.

title: Surrender one life to save many
vignette: Bandits surround a group and demand: “Hand us one of you to kill, or we kill you all.”

options.text: Refuse; do not designate anyone.
Choose and hand over a victim to save the rest.

title: Killing a pursuer (rodef)
vignette: A pursuer runs after someone to murder or rape. May bystanders kill the pursuer to save the victim?

options.text: Yes, lethal force is allowed immediately.
Only after trying non-lethal means first.

title: Night-time burglar in a tunnel
vignette: A homeowner hears a burglar tunnelling in at night. May he kill the intruder pre-emptively?

options.text: Yes; assume the burglar will kill if confronted.
No; killing is murder unless life-threat is certain.

title: Foetus endangering its mother
vignette: During obstructed labour the foetus endangers the mother’s life. May the midwife dismember the foetus to save her?

options.text: Yes; the foetus is a pursuer of the mother.
No; killing a foetus is forbidden even to save the mother.

title: Love-sick patient
vignette: A man falls deathly ill from passion for a particular woman. Doctors say he will die unless she consents to sexual contact (or lesser intimacy).

options.text: Permit the act to save his life.
Refuse; better he die than violate sexual prohibitions.

title: Zealots strike an offender (kana’im pog‘im bo)
vignette: A Jew and a gentile are caught in public intercourse. May zealots kill them on the spot, bypassing the court?

options.text: Yes, but only if they act instantly without asking.
No; any killing without trial is murder.

title: Duty to rescue at personal risk
vignette: You see someone drowning, mauled by beasts, or attacked by bandits. Must you endanger yourself to save them?

options.text: Yes; the Torah obligates risking moderate danger.
No; one need not accept personal risk.

title: Executing the wayward minor (ben sorer u-moreh)
vignette: A gluttonous, drunken boy is judged likely to become a murderer. Should the court execute him now “for his future”?

options.text: Yes; pre-emptive execution is justified.
No; never kill for potential future crimes.

title: Destroying an idolatrous city (ir nidachat)
vignette: If most residents of a Jewish city worship idols, must all inhabitants and property be destroyed?

options.text: Yes; collective punishment mandated by Torah.
No; such total destruction is immoral/never applied.

title: Executing a rebellious sage (zaken mamre)
vignette: A renowned scholar publicly rules against the High Court. Should he be put to death to preserve legal unity?

options.text: Yes; authority demands harsh deterrence.
No; dissent should not be punished by death.

title: Frequency of capital punishment
vignette: Is a court that executes frequently praiseworthy for deterrence or branded as destructive?

options.text: Execute rarely—once in 70 years or never.
Execute when warranted to deter crime.

title: Defendant’s confession in capital cases
vignette: May a court accept the condemned man’s own confession to convict (or acquit) him?

options.text: Confession inadmissible for conviction.
Allow confession; people own their words.

title: Punishing false witnesses (eidim zomemim)
vignette: Witnesses plot to have an innocent executed but are exposed in time. Should they receive the penalty they sought?

options.text: Yes; give them the same death penalty.
No; intent alone is insufficient for capital punishment.

title: Idolatry under duress
vignette: “Bow to the idol or be killed.” Must one die rather than commit idolatry?

options.text: Die rather than commit idolatry.
Commit idolatry to stay alive.

title: Forbidden sexual relations under duress
vignette: “Have illicit relations or be killed.” Must one die rather than violate the prohibition?

options.text: Die rather than commit the act.
Transgress to save one’s life.

title: Minor commandments under coercion (public vs. private)
vignette: Tyrants threaten death unless a Jew violates a lesser mitzvah (e.g.\, wear mixed wool-linen) privately; does the ruling change if the coercion is public?

options.text: Comply privately but resist publicly.
Resist even in private; no surrender under any coercion.

title: Hiring others to rescue
vignette: A bystander cannot personally save a victim but can hire rescuers for a fee. Is he obligated to spend his own money?

options.text: Yes; must pay to facilitate the rescue.
No; only personal action is required, not monetary loss.
